description: The United Kingdom advises against all non-essential travel from March 17 for a period of 30 days.

description: On March 23, The UK advises all British travellers to return to the UK.
type_sub_cat: Visa extensions (e.g. visa validity extended)

description: Public Health England has been directed to trace all individuals that have traveled back to the UK from Wuhan in the past 14 days. Anyone that has traveled back from Wuhan has been asked to self-isolate for 14 days.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: Regulations on public health for Scotland has been amended, making covid-19 a notifiable disease. Medical practitioners are now required to show health boards patient information, in case there are reasonable grounds that the patient has covid-19. The amendment to the Public Health (Scotland) Act 2008 was announced on the 22 February on the Scottish government's website and will take effect the same day.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: As of February 26th, health minister Robin Swann announced that "any confirmed cases in Northern Ireland will be admitted to the Regional Infectious Disease Unit (RIDU) in the Royal Victoria Hospital, Belfast, if the patient is aged 16 years or over. If the patient is under 16 they will be admitted to the Royal Belfast Hospital for Sick Children."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: As part of Northern Ireland's contact tracing pilot program, released on April 27 2020, “ if a person experiences COVID-19 symptoms and self-isolates”, “ they should order a test”, continue to self-isolate if the test returns positive, and share information regarding “close contacts” and “places visited” when contacted by the PHA.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: As part of Northern Ireland's contact tracing pilot program, released on April 27 2020, “those contacted by the PHA” and “advised to self-isolate” can only request a test if they have symptoms. This does not apply to “HSC staff, healthcare workers and care providers”, for whom “separate guidance” is in place.
type_sub_cat: NA
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: As a part of Northern Ireland's contract tracing pilot program, released April 27 2020, "when responding to employees who fail to comply" in informing employers about being contacted by the PHA, "employers must act reasonably, fairly and in a non-discriminatory manner."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: As part of Northern Ireland's contact tracing pilot program, released April 27 2020, while "self-isolation is not mandatory, currently", and "some employees may disregard the notification on financial or other grounds", "employers should inform their employees that they are required to inform the employer if they are contacted by the PHA."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: As a part of Northern Ireland's contact tracing pilot program,released on April 27 2020, the PHA will contact individuals for whom tests return positive and then “decide whether to contact those who have been in close contact with the person testing positive, without revealing their identity.” “The PHA states that personal data is confidential, will not be shared and will be kept and used only in line with data protection laws.”
type_sub_cat: NA

description: As part of North Ireland's contact tracing pilot program, released April 27 2020, "to comply with data protection laws, employers must ensure that their collection and further use of information",relating to individuals being contacted by the PHA, "(and the lawful reason for asking for it) is set out in existing employee notices, or that they are updated, if not."
type_sub_cat: NA
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: The England region in the United Kingdom announced that the country is ramping up their mass testing program to accommodate for testing 150,000 people every fortnight by October.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: UK aid will support WHO's Flash Appeal to stop the spread of coronavirus in developing countries with £5 million. This includes training of staff and spreading awareness of the disease.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description: From the 10 February, the National Health Service Scotland (United Kingdom) will start running two Corona testing facilities that have just been established. The new testing laboratories will process all Corona tests from Scotland in Glasgow and Edinburgh instead of sending it to London. Negative tests can be quicker processed, but positive tests still need to be sent to London for a confirmatory test. The new facilities are established in NHS existing laboratories in the two cities. The policy is targeting to all people that are being Corona-tested.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: "To relieve potential pressures on global supply chains, [UK] suppliers have been asked to carry out a risk assessment on the impact of coronavirus on their business. As an extra precaution, companies have also been asked to retain existing stockpiles of medical supplies, compiled as a contingency measure ahead of [the UK's] exit from the EU, where possible"
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Part of Scotland's preparations for the coronavirus is to supply general practitioner surgeries with face masks and making sure hospitals are equipped with personal protective equipment. This was announced on a resilience meeting on the 25th February chaired by the Scottish Government Resilience (SGoR).
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: As of March 2nd, health minister Robin Swann announces that “Northern Ireland now has full access to the NHS 111 helpline on coronavirus. This is available 24/7 to provide advice.”
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure

description:
"On 18 March the Defence Secretary announced new measures to enable armed forces personnel to support public services in response to the coronavirus outbreak."
This includes "providing medical and logistical support for the NHS; acting as liaison officers; and deploying specialist skills such as engineering and accounting."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 18, the UK asks retired healthcare professionals, including GPs, doctors, pharmacists, nurses, midwives, NHS 111 advisers and social care staff, to come back and help the NHS.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 24, The UK Government launches a new scheme to 250,000 volunteers to support the NHS through the coronavirus pandemic, consisting of "people in good health to help the NHS, for shopping, for the delivery of medicines and to support those who are shielding to protect their own health"
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 27, the Welsh government (UK) announced that the national stadium of Wales, the Principality Stadium, is to be used as a field hospital for up to 2,000 beds to help fight the coronavirus.
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Scotland to improve the distribution system of personal protective equipment (PPE) for health and social care staff with the delivery of eight weeks' worth of PPE to all general practitioners' surgeries and, adding to  well-established arrangements in hospitals, all health boards now have a single point of contact to manage local PPE supply and distribution from 30 March 2020.

description: Scotland pauses health screening programmes for the Scotland's National Health Service from 30 March 2020.

description: Scotland will create a temporary hospital with an initial 300 beds in the Scottish Events Campus in Glasgow with work starting from 30 March 2020.

description: On April 4, the UK Health Minister launches a new online 'Coronavirus Status Checker' survey system to collect additional data on the outbreak.

description:
In the UK, "a clinical trial has been given approval to determine if plasma donated by patients who have recovered from COVID-19 can help those battling the illness".
"The collection of plasma would be ramped up over April and May to deliver up to 10,000 units of plasma to the NHS every week, enough to treat 5,000 COVID-19 patients per week."
type_sub_cat: Other Health Infrastructure
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Scotland establishes more than fifty Emergency Eyecare Treatment Centres on 25 April 2020.

description: Face coverings must be worn in additional enclosed public spaces from 24 July in England, as the government takes further steps to help curb the spread of the virus.

description: The coronavirus test developed by Public Health England is being rolled out to laboratories across the UK, allowing for around 1000 people to be tested per day for England alone.

description: "On Monday 27 April 2020, the Northern Ireland Public Health Agency (PHA) commenced a pilot programme of contact tracing which is helping to inform the planned roll-out of a Northern Ireland-wide contact tracing programme, as requested by the Department of Health."
type_sub_cat: NA

description: New ways to test covid-19 is being set up across Scotland. On the 28 February, National Health Service (NHS) Lothian was the first to set up a drive-through testing centre for the coronavirus in Edinburgh. Drive through testing will be set up in other parts of Scotland too. Other NHS have established other testing arrangements, like community testing.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: "Boris Johnson set out a new target of capacity for 200,000 tests a day by the end of May"
type_sub_cat: NA

description: "Prime Minister Boris Johnson has pledged tests would be processed within 24 hours by the end of June"
type_sub_cat: NA

description: The UK will be placed into Category B starting August 1, 2020. The health ministry reiterated that passengers arriving from Category B countries are required to present a negative test result taken within the last three days.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: From 17 August 2020, all contacts of COVID-19 index cases will be offered testing regardless of whether they have symptoms. At present, recent close contacts of those people with a positive test result, are asked to isolate for 14 days. While they will still have to do this, they will now also be advised to get a test, allowing for further contacts to be identified and potential, wider outbreaks contained.
type_sub_cat: NA

description: From 1 September 2020, Scotland will participate in the UK's Office for National Statistics COVID-19 Infection Survey. This represents the single biggest expansion to date of asymptomatic testing for surveillance purposes in the pandemic. The survey will eventually see approximately 15,000 individuals in Scotland tested during every two-week rolling period. This equates to approximately 9,000 households.
type_sub_cat: NA
enforcer: National Government,Provincial/State Government,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
The England region in the UK published a set of hygiene guidelines on March 12, 2020 by the NHS to help workers in the healthcare field practice proper sanitation methods. This list includes guidelines for:
• patient placement/assessment for infection risk
• hand hygiene
• respiratory and cough hygiene
• personal protective equipment (PPE)
• safe management of care equipment
• safe management of the care environment
• safe management of linen
• safe management of blood and body fluids
• safe disposal of waste (including sharps)
• occupational safety/managing prevention of exposure (including sharps).
type_sub_cat: Other Areas Hygiene Measures Applied
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: From 13 July, people in Scotland are advised against travelling to North West England. Travel between Scotland and Greater Manchester, East Lancashire and parts of West Yorkshire should only be undertaken if absolutely essential.
type_sub_cat: NA
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: On March 23, the UK government imposes an essential lockdown, restricting people from leaving their homes except for four limited purposes: shopping, exercise, medical needs and travelling to and from work if absolutely necessary. Gatherings of two or more people, except members of households, are prohibited and will dispersed.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Scotland to introduce lockdown with a ban on gatherings of more than two people from 23 March 2020.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: On April 15th, first minister Arlene Foster of Northern Ireland announced that the lockdown which was imposed in late March will remain in place until May 5th.

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: As of May 12th, a five-stage plan for easing the COVID-19 lockdown in Northern Ireland has been published by the executive. Phase one encourages those unable to work from home to return to work on a phased basis, allows opening of large outdoor-based retail  including garden centres, though associated cafes and restaurants can only offer takeaway or collection, allows groups of four to six people who do not share a household to meet outdoors maintaining social distancing, allows visits to immediate family indoors where social distancing is possible unless people are shielding, allows for opening of drive-through church services and churches for private prayer, with appropriate social distancing and cleaning of shared contact hard surfaces, and allows outdoor spaces, public sport amenities, and drive-through cinemas to open.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: As of May 12th, a five-stage plan for easing the COVID-19 lock down in Northern Ireland has been published by the executive. During phase two, non-food retail can open where numbers are limited with social distancing, groups of up to 10 can meet outdoors, as demand increases on public transport within social distancing requirements, people are encouraged to walk and cycle for short journeys where possible, team sports training on a non-contact basis in small groups can resume, selected libraries can reopen with restricted services, and open-air museums can re-open.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: As of May 12th, a five-stage plan for easing the COVID-19 lockdown in Northern Ireland has been published by the executive. During phase three, a phased return to office and onsite working will be subject to risk assessment,  work that can be done from home should still be done from home, schools will expand provision for priority groups on a part-time basis, using a combination of in-school and remote learning, gatherings can accommodate up to 30 people while maintaining social distancing, team sports training on a non-contact basis can resume, museums, galleries, and libraries can open, and concert and theatre rehearsals can resume.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: As of May 12th, a five-stage plan for easing the COVID-19 lockdown in Northern Ireland has been published by the executive. During phase four, "contact" retail (hairdressers, fitness studios, tattoo and piercing parlours) can open subject to mitigations following risk assessment, schools can expand provision to accommodate all pupils on part-time basis with combination of in-school and remote learning, demand for public transport will be reduced and staggered at peak times through continued home working and staggered start times for businesses, a wider range of gatherings will be permitted including church services subject to social distancing and other suitable mitigations, such as cleaning of hard surfaces, competitive sport "behind closed doors" or with limitations on the number of spectators can resume, leisure centres and other indoor leisure facilities can open, and outdoor concerts can resume on a restricted basis.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: As of May 12th, a five-stage plan for easing the COVID-19 lockdown in Northern Ireland has been published by the executive. During phase 5 (the final phase), all will be able to return to work subject to mitigations, remote working will still be strongly encouraged, hospitality retail (restaurants, cafes, pubs) can open subject to risk assessment, initially on a limited basis, early-year school provision can be expanded to full-time basis, public transport will be operating full service but subject to ongoing risk assessment, people can meet in extended groups subject to social distancing, close physical contact sports can resume, there can be return to competitive sport and full use of sporting facilities, spectators can attend live events on a restricted basis, and nightclubs, concerts will open on a limited basis.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
As of March 28th in Northern Ireland, the executive put lockdown measures in place. "The regulations include that no-one may leave their home without reasonable excuse. These include: to obtain basic necessities, including food and medical supplies; to take exercise either alone or with other members of their household; to seek medical assistance; to provide care or assistance to a vulnerable person and to get to work." Additionally, unless everyone is from the same household, gatherings of more than two people in public places are not allowed. Regulations have also been put on businesses as part of the lockdown measures. Only some can remain open and those who can must work from home.
 UPDATE: The housing market in Northern Ireland had been closed, but beginning Monday June 15th, it has reopened.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)
compliance: Mandatory with Fines,Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: England eases their COVID-19 lockdown by opening up pubs, restaurants and hairdressers starting July 4, 2020. These places can be accessed by all members of the general public and this is a Lockdown policy that is being eased.
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: On March 27th, "Taoiseach (Irish prime minister) Leo Varadkar introduced a mandatory order for everyone to stay at home for a two-week period until 12 April, apart from certain exceptions, across the Republic of Ireland."
type_sub_cat: Lockdown only applies to people of certain ages (Please note the age restriction in the text box)

description: Activation of the Scottish Government Resilience Room (SGoRR), with the aim to coordinate all Scottish Government activity in response to coronavirus.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: As of March 9th, health minister of Northern Ireland,Robin Swann, announced that "At operational level a Regional Surge Planning Sub-group has been established by the PHA and the HSCB to ensure that there is an appropriate and proportionate level of HSC preparedness across the sector in response to Covid-19. "
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: On March 17, UK Prime Minister sets up new ministerial structures to coordinate, prioritise and respond to the coronavirus pandemic across government, including one for Healthcare, General Public Sector, Economic and Business and International.
type: New Task Force, Bureau or Administrative Configuration
type_sub_cat: New Task Force or Bureau (i.e. establishment of a temporary body)

description: UK government pledges £20 million to fund the development of a vaccines for coronavirus and other infectious diseases
type_sub_cat: NA

description: Foreign Secretary, "Dominic Raab has confirmed the evacuation flight back to the UK for British people on the Diamond Princess in Japan, following the coronavirus outbreak."
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Evacuation flight organised for British nationals on the Diamond Princess in Japan following the coronavirus outbreak

description: UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson announces statutory sick pay, which is now available from the first day of sickness rather than the usual fourth day.
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Statutory sick pay available on the first day of sickness rather than the fourth day

description: The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) "will consider any evidence that companies may have broken competition or consumer protection law, for example by charging excessive prices or making misleading claims about the efficacy of protective equipment. And it will take direct enforcement action in appropriate cases."
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Restriction of businesses in order to prevent exploitation
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description:
"At 6.15pm on 5 March 2020, a statutory instrument was made into [UK] law that adds COVID-19 to the list of notifiable diseases and SARS-COV-2 to the list of notifiable causative agents."
"This change in law requires GPs to report all cases of COVID-19 to Public Health England."
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Coronavirus was added to the list of notifiable diseases in UK law. "This change in law requires GPs to report all cases of COVID-19 to Public Health England."

description: Government outlines further plans to maximise the number of volunteers. "Volunteers – who already play a central role in helping the health and social care system function – will be given additional employment safeguards so they can leave their main jobs and temporarily volunteer in the event of a widespread pandemic."
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Employment safeguards so they can leave their main jobs and temporarily volunteer in the event of a widespread pandemic.

description: People in Scotland aged over 70 and those who have high risk and underlying health conditions are strongly advised to stay at home as much as possible and significantly reduce unnecessary social contact from 16 March 2020.
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Those in high risk categories (aged over 70 or with underlying health conditions) advised to limit social contact.

description: Scottish government announces that key health and social workers will have priority in getting tested for coronavirus from 24 March 2020.
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Key health and social workers in Scotland to have priority in getting tested for coronavirus.

description: On March 30, the UK Government announces a new government partnership with airlines (Virgin, Easyjet, Jet2 and Titan Airways) to fly back more tourists stranded abroad due to the coronavirus pandemic.
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Repatriation in the form of "government chartered flights from priority countries to UK over the weekend and more to take place this week and up to £75 million government funding pledged to bring UK travellers back home"

description: England is implementing "technology support for children and schools during coronavirus" to assist their remote learning. This support is available for underprivileged Year 10 pupils, care leavers, and children/ young people between the ages 0 and 19 with social workers.
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Department of Education in England is providing technology support for underprivileged pupils who meet a criteria to assist their remote learning.
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description:
"The [UK] government will temporarily ban the use of statutory demands (made between 1 March 2020 and 30 June 2020) and winding up petitions presented from Monday 27 April, through to 30 June, where a company cannot pay its bills due to coronavirus. This will help ensure these companies do not fall into deeper financial strain. The measures will be included in the Corporate Insolvency and Governance Bill".
"Government is also laying secondary legislation to provide tenants with more breathing space to pay rent by preventing landlords using Commercial Rent Arrears Recovery (CRAR) unless they are owed 90 days of unpaid rent."
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: The policy aims to collaborate with tenants and companies to prevent aggressive debt rent recovery during the pandemic
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: Test and Protect – NHS Scotland’s approach to controlling the spread of coronavirus (COVID-19) in the community – will be rolled out across all health boards from Thursday, May 28. From that date, everyone aged five and over who has COVID-19 symptoms of a new continuous cough, temperature or loss or change in sense of taste or smell should go to NHS Inform online or call 0800 028 2816 to book a test. Under the system, people will need to isolate with their household as soon as they have symptoms and, if they have a positive test result, they will be asked to provide details of all recent close contacts to NHS contact tracers.  Those people will be contacted and asked to isolate for 14 days.
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: Test and protect policy announced whereby people will need to isolate with their household as soon as they have symptoms of coronavirus and, if they have a positive test result, they will be asked to provide details of all recent close contacts to NHS contact tracers. Those people will be contacted and asked to isolate for 14 days.

description: As part of Scotland's Test and Protect system, from 14 August it is mandatory for hospitality settings to collect the contact details of visitors to their premises in support of Test and Protect. The new regulations apply to restaurants, cafes, pubs and hotels in which food or drink are sold for consumption on the premises.
type_sub_cat: NA
type_text: As part of Scotland's Test and Protect system, from 14 August it is mandatory for hospitality settings to collect the contact details of visitors to their premises in support of Test and Protect. The new regulations apply to restaurants, cafes, pubs and hotels in which food or drink are sold for consumption on the premises.

description: On January 20, Public Health England in the UK advises people travelling to Wuhan, China to "maintain good hand, respiratory and personal hygiene and should avoid visiting animal and bird markets or people who are ill with respiratory symptoms. Individuals should seek medical attention if they develop respiratory symptoms within 14 days of visiting Wuhan [...]".
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: A UK Foreign & Commonwealth Office spokesperson advised against non-essential travel to Wuhan, and advised UK nationals travelling to Wuhan to remain vigilant.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: UK government funds a campaign to help inform the public of safer practices in order to slow the spread of coronavirus and reduce the burden to the NHS
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: British Embassy in Beijing provides a Q&A regarding coronavirus for British nationals and their dependents currently in China
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On the 27 February, the Health Protection Scotland (HPS) published guidelines on how to prevent the spread of the coronavirus, how to act if staff or students fall ill, information on web teaching resources about hygiene practices, and others. The guidance was distributed to “schools, colleges, universities and early learning and childcare providers in Scotland” and “all colleges and universities by the Scottish Funding Council and independent schools via Education Scotland, and grant aided special schools”.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: On March 3, The United Kingdom publishes its Coronavirus Action Plan.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: The health and social care system across the UK created a 'Coronavirus (COVID-19) action plan. "This document sets out what the UK as a whole has done – and plans to do – to tackle the coronavirus (COVID-19) outbreak, based on [their] experience dealing with other infectious diseases and [their] influenza pandemic preparedness work."
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: A public information campaign focusing on the importance of washing hands for 20 seconds has been started in the UK to slow down the spread of coronavirus. "The campaign will appear in the print media, radio, online and in public places, including billboards".
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: In Scotland, new guidance has been issued on coronavirus that includes workplace advice. Issued on March 9, it targets non-healthcare settings such as hotels, leisure facilities, entertainment venues and other work environments or public spaces. The guidance consists of basic hygiene measures and advice from Health Protection Scotland to prevent the spread of infection, including guidance on hand washing, routine cleaning, among other advice on measures that can help prevent the spread of Corona. There is no information on an end-date.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On March 28, the UK launches an information service on WhatsApp.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: On April 6 in Wales (UK), The Public Health Wales’ Coronavirus Surveillance Cell have launched an interactive data dashboard to enable the health system, the public and media in Wales to find out more about the virus in Wales.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: UK is providing guidance to UK consumers regarding food hygiene in response to the coronavirus outbreak.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate
enforcer: Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: The United Kingdom's government provided a set of guidelines to help the citizens of England get access to public and mental health resources during this COVID-19 pandemic. This article was last updated on August 4, 2020 and continues to be a helpful resource for citizens to use as they nagivate their lives through the pandmeic.
type_sub_cat: Disseminating information related to COVID-19 to the public that is reliable and factually accurate

description: 'The Health Protection (Coronavirus) Regulations 2020' has been put together to impose restrictions on individuals at risk of spreading coronavirus in the UK. "The regulations apply to any individuals seeking to leave supported isolation before the current quarantine period of 14 days is complete"
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 12, Scotland’s Chief Medical Officer announced that people with symptoms (fever or cough) that can be coronavirus (COVID-19) should stay at home for seven days. Those who have been in contact with other persons experiencing symptoms do not need to stay at home, unless they also develop symptoms. The advice about home-stay takes effect on March 13.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: A geographical or administrative unit within a country

description: On March 12, The United Kingdom announced that from March 13, people with a fever or a new 'continuous' cough should self-isolate for 7 days.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 16, The UK government asked the public to ensure "that if you or anyone in your household has one of those two symptoms [a high temperature or a new and continuous cough], then you should stay at home for fourteen days." UPDATE: The UK originally advised those with symptoms to self-isolate for 14 days, the PM has extended that to entire households of people with symptoms.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: On March 23, the UK government imposes an essential lockdown, restricting people from leaving their homes except for four limited purposes: shopping, exercise, medical needs and travelling to and from work if absolutely necessary. Gatherings of two or more people, except members of households, are prohibited and will dispersed. UPDATE: On March 23, the UK government imposes stricter social distancing measures and imposes the possibility of penalties for violations.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
target_geog_level: One or more countries, but not all countries

description: As part of Northern Ireland's contact tracing pilot program, released on April 27 2020, “where the employee has no symptoms but is advised by the PHA to self-isolate for 14 days and cannot work from home, they will be eligible to receive statutory sick pay”, although “some employers may, instead, pay company sick pay or full pay for the duration of any such period of isolation.”
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
compliance: Mandatory (Other; please list other enforcement mechanisms in the text entry)

description: From the 8 June 2020, individuals entering the UK must quarantine and self-isolate for 14 days. Lorry drivers, seasonal farm workers, and coronavirus medics will be exempt. The requirement will also not apply to those travelling from the Republic of Ireland, the Channel Islands and the Isle of Man.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: While previously, anyone entering Northern Ireland from outside the Common Travel Area had to self-isolate for fourteen days, it was announced on July 9th that beginning July 10th, there is "no self-isolation requirement for those travelling to Northern Ireland from low to medium risk countries". "People arriving in Northern Ireland from more than 50 countries including France, Spain, Germany and Italy are now no longer required to quarantine."
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)
compliance: Mandatory with Exceptions (Please list exceptions in the text entry)

description: While previously, anyone entering Northern Ireland from outside the Common Travel Area had to self-isolate for fourteen days, it was announced on July 9th that beginning July 10th, there is "no self-isolation requirement for those travelling to Northern Ireland from low to medium risk countries". "People arriving in Northern Ireland from more than 50 countries including France, Spain, Germany and Italy are now no longer required to quarantine." UPDATE: As of July 10th, NI's chief medical officer has said that from Saturday (July 11th) Serbia will be removed from the list of countries exempt from quarantine rules.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: All household contacts of factory workers from the 2 Sisters factor in Coupar Angus Scotland are advised to self-isolate from 17 August 2020 to 31 August 2020.
type_sub_cat: Self-Quarantine (i.e. quarantine at home)

description: The Scottish Government is telling businesses including cafes, pubs, and restaurants to close, along with nightclubs, theatres, cinemas, gyms, casinos, betting shops, bingo halls, concert halls and leisure centres from 20 March 2020. UPDATE: From 15 July 2020, indoor restaurants, cafes and pubs in Scotland are allowed to re-open. Additionally in Scotland, all holiday accommodation can re-open from 15 July, as well as the childcare sector, hairdressers and barbers. Museums, galleries, cinemas and libraries can also open from 15 July, with strict physical distancing and for many of these facilities advanced ticketing will be required.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: On March 20, the UK announces that all cafes, pubs, bars, restaurants,  nightclubs, theatres, cinemas, gyms and leisure centres should close as soon as they reasonably can on March 20, and not to open on March 21.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: The Scottish Government is telling businesses including cafes, pubs, and restaurants to close, along with nightclubs, theatres, cinemas, gyms, casinos, betting shops, bingo halls, concert halls and leisure centres from 20 March 2020.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: March 24th, NI announced Supermarkets (excluding cafes within), convenience stores and corner shops, Grocery markets – excluding farmers/hot food/street food markets, Local fresh food suppliers like butchers/fishmongers and bakeries, Hot food takeaways - not allowing option to eat in,Pharmacies/Chemists and Health food shops, Dental surgeries, opticians, audiology, physiotherapy, chiropody and other professional vocational medical services – for urgent appointments, Veterinary clinics and pet shops, Newsagents, Hardware/building supplies stores, Retail services in hospitals, Petrol stations, garages, auto repair shops for urgent work, High street banks, credit unions and cash points, Post offices,Funeral directors, crematoriums and related, Laundrettes and dry cleaners, Storage/distribution facilities, including delivery drop-off points, Medical or storage services, Public car parks in towns and cities near food takeaway services, and Public toilets can stay OPEN while Clothes and Electronics shops, Hair, beauty and nail salons, non-essential retail shops, other indoor and outdoor markets including non-food markets and car boot sales, Hotels, hostels, Bed and Breakfasts, Caravan Parks, Camping sites, Boarding Houses - except where caravans and mobile homes are being used as permanent residences and where hotels are providing emergency accommodation, Libraries, Community/youth centers, places of worship, indoor recreation sites and Enclosed spaces in public parks must CLOSE
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: From Monday, 8 June, as Northern Ireland moves into phase 1 of reopening, business by outdoor non-food retailers will also be permitted, including new and used car retailers; retailers of light motor vehicles, lorries/trailers; retailers of caravans or motorhomes, and retailers of agricultural or other large machinery.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: On June 11th, the executive office in Northern Ireland announced that from  Friday, 12 June, the remainder of the ‘non-contact’ retail sector will reopen.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description:
The United Kingdom has published guidelines to allow researchers and lab staff continue to work in their businesses safely while following the recommended health guidelines. This document is to help employers,
employees and the self-employed in the UK understand how
to work safely during this pandemic.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses
enforcer: Ministry/Department of Health,Other (Please specify in the text box)

description: In the Aberdeen City local authority area in Scotland from 5pm on 5 August government restrictions on non-essential businesses will be re-imposed. Bars, restaurants, cafes and pubs will be required by law to close. Hotel restaurants can remain open to provide food for existing guests, and takeaway services can continue.
type_sub_cat: All or unspecified non-essential businesses

description: Scotland to introduce lockdown with a ban on gatherings of more than two people from 23 March 2020. UPDATE: Scotland to ease lockdown from 29 May 2020. From 29 May 2020, one household can now meet up with another outdoors. This can be in one household’s garden, but physical distancing is still required. It is expected households will only meet one other household within the same day and up to a recommended maximum of eight people in the overall group. Additionally, people in Scotland cantravel short distances for outdoor leisure and exercise but should remain in your local area, suggested to be five miles from your house, although we ask people to use their judgement. From 29 May 2020,public outdoor spaces can now be used for recreational purposes, for example to sit in a park, sunbathe or have a picnic. People should not share food and drink between households and should avoid using shared facilities, such as bathrooms. If eating, each household should bring their own food separately and avoid sharing utensils, dishes or cups and use a hand sanitiser before eating. Physical distancing between households should be maintained at all times.
type_sub_cat: Postponement of an annually recurring event

description: The United Kingdom, specifically England, published a new set of guidelines starting on July 4, 2020, which limit all wedding ceremonies to a maximum of 30 people. This is a Restriction of Mass Gatherings policy which is targeted towards all citizens and general public in England.

description: In the workplace in Scotland, a social distance of 2m should be adhered to whenever possible from 1 April 2020. When it is not possible to implement the 2m social distancing guidance at the workplace, a brief risk assessment should be undertaken as the whether the task is essential and if so, the distance between workers can be reduced to no less than 1m, out with break times when the 2m social distance guidance applies

description: From 15 July 2020, there will be exemptions to the 2m social distancing rule in Scotland for public transport, retail and hospitality sectors to allow a move from 2m to 1m physical distancing. This is conditional on appropriate additional mitigating measures being implemented to reduce the elevated risk associated with a 1m distance as oppose to 2m. For the purpose of this guidance, hospitality sectors relates to public houses, restaurants and cafes, including those where they are situated within other premises, such as hotels, visitor attractions and clubs.
type_sub_cat: Keeping a distance of at least 6 feet or 1.5 meters apart

description: Scotland is to make face coverings compulsory across more indoor public settings from 8 August 2020. Settings where face coverings must be legally worn in Scotland is expanding to include certain indoor public places such as cinemas, galleries, museums and banks.

description: From 31 August 2020, face coverings should be worn in secondary schools by adults and all pupils moving around the school, such as in corridors and communal areas where physical distancing is difficult to maintain and on dedicated school transport by all children aged five and over, bringing it into line with guidance for public transport in Scotland.
